Highlights

You and Sarah are both in Climate Change / ESG Professionals Group, Green Innovators Network (GIN) for Sustainability and Innovation by GreenInnovatorsNetwork.org , and 2 others

About

A secondary science educator with leadership experience, I have a passion for problem solving in the fields of both education and applied sciences. I am interested in work that is founded on the mitigation of anthropogenic issues and the reversal of global ecological vulnerability, while also having a strong desire to garner excellence in K-12 public schools (i.e. academic coaching). I am eagerly receptive to any requisite training or certification and willing to adapt to roles that diversify my skill set. My interests include public education, multiculturalism, data analysis, permaculture, biodiversity alignment, sustainable infrastructure, phytoremediation, and applications of biomimicry and biogeochemical cycles. I have a passion for high leverage approaches to problem solving, and I aspire to coordinate projects and personnel as a means to collaboratively regain informed stewardship of our youth and our environment.

Please see my resume uploaded to my profile. References are available upon request in order to protect the private information of referring individuals. 

I appreciate your time and interest.

2mo • 

Building with Clothes 🧱👕

2 kg of textile waste = 1 brick.


Europe produces over 4 million tons of textile waste every year 👕🚮?!

French startup FabBRICK® is turning his challenge into an opportunity: transforming discarded clothes into durable building bricks 🧱✨.

👉 Fact 1: Each FabBRICK block is made from ~2 kg of textile waste, giving old clothes a second life as soundproof, insulating construction material.

👉 Fact 2: Since 2019, they’ve up-cycled over 100 tons of textile . 🌱

This is circular economy in action—waste becomes resource, pollution becomes solution. 💡

💬 What do you think: Could your city be built with FabBRICK?

#circulareconomy #innovation
Credit:NoPolluting

India is also going places by producing stone paper, along with several other nations. India’s stone paper market is experiencing rapid growth: it generated $58.7 million in revenue in 2024 and is projected to more than double by 2033, driven by demand for sustainable packaging and labeling. Indian manufacturers such as Bonafide Exp, Crest Container Line Pvt Ltd, Damco India Pvt Limited, Noble Industries, and Sumela Exp Pvt Ltd are actively producing stone paper, primarily for packaging uses.

Sam Knowlton

Founder & Managing Director at SoilSymbiotics

1yr • 

When Europeans arrived in North America, up to 60 million bison roamed the great plains.

These iconic grazers turned the prairie soils into a deep carbon sponge, vibrant with biological activity.

Often overlooked in this story is the vast diversity of plants carpeting the plains.

The great plains are home to ~ 3,000 plant species, most of which are grasses and forbs grazed by bison.

Many of these plants feature massive and intricate root systems that makeup around 90% of the plant's total biomass.

The top 4-6 feet of soil is full of roots.

Each plant species has a unique root architecture to ensure its space amongst all the other roots in the soil. 

Plant roots supply a blend of sugars, enzymes, organic acids, phenols, and other compounds that recruit and sustain specific soil microbes based on the plants' needs.

The greater the diversity of plants, the greater the diversity of roots and microbes, and the more robust the below and aboveground ecosystems. 

As an example of the profound cycle of life, the bison catalyzed life within the soil that in turn bolstered its own existence.

Regenerative Agriculture Industry Network

Sarah Herzog • 1st

1yr • 

Reposted... 50-80% water savings.

Sam Knowlton 
 • Following

Founder & Managing Director at SoilSymbiotics

1yr • 

Rajendra Singh, also known as the waterman of India, led efforts to build 14,000 water harvesting structures that capture 1.3 billion liters of water each year, turning water-scarce regions of India into oases.

His work has revitalized more than a dozen "dead" rivers, recharged depleted water tables, and ensured water security for 1,500 Indian villages.

Rajendra and the organization he heads, Tarun Bharat Sangh (TBS), have helped implement efficient irrigation strategies and water harvesting on more than 5,000 farms, achieving a 50-80% water savings and a 20-30% increase in farmer income.

The abundance of captured water has allowed for a massive afforestation effort. In just two years, TBS transformed a barren wasteland into two sq km of dense forest, which has become the country's first conservation sanctuary.
Rajendra and TBS have now trained more than 100,000 practitioners and volunteers who continue the community-based efforts to restore the water cycle.

The work of restoring ecosystems, repairing water systems, and rescuing farmland from the brink of collapse does not have to be complicated.

In the high-tech and bureaucracy driven era we live in, low-tech community-based initiatives are overlooked and even scoffed at. However, as demonstrated by Rajendra’s incredible work such initiatives can have an outsized impact.

To think... what all we are discovering, and what all there must be left to discover that we cannot yet fathom. How will new technologies look in the future, and how can we ensure that life is respected while we simultaneously aim to harness its seemingly effortless power and complexity?

Sam Knowlton 
 • Following

Founder & Managing Director at SoilSymbiotics

1yr • 

This video shows real-time carbon flows inside a mycorrhizal network. 

Mycorrhizal fungi form a symbiotic relationship with ~ 90% of terrestrial plants and have done so for 400 million years.

These specialized fungi provide plants with nutrients and water in exchange for carbon-based exudates the plant produces through photosynthesis. 

Current estimates say that between 4 and 20 percent of all CO2 pulled in by plants ends up stored in mycorrhizal tissues. 

Considering plants need to build an entire above-ground structure, a root system, and produce flowers, fruits, and seeds, this is an astounding amount of carbon to allocate to mycorrhizal biomass. 

A recent review study estimates that global plant communities transfer 13.1 gigatons of CO2 to the underground mycelium of mycorrhizal fungi each year – equivalent to roughly 1/3 of annual CO2 emissions from fossil fuels. 

The amount of time the carbon is locked up in fungi’s mycelium remains unknown. Nonetheless, the influx of such a massive amount of carbon into the soil is a boon for soil ecology, nutrient cycling, and the health of water cycles. 

It is no wonder the formation of terrestrial ecosystems largely started with the mycorrhizal fungi/plant partnership. 

Video credit: Rachael Cargill
